tutorial.title: Waves Pattern
tutorial.descriptionContent: Use loops to display a wave pattern in the console.

executableContent.instructions:
A developer tried displaying an asterisk `*` and tildes `~` in the console to simulate a beach. The `*` for the sun and the `~` for the waves.

Sadly, there are some mistakes.

Before we start, take a look at the output the programmer was trying to achieve:

```JS
*
~
~~
~~~
~~~~
~~~~~
```

Now let's look at the code they wrote and start fixing it. The while loop is using a `counter` variable. But does that exist in the code?

1. Start by creating the counter variable used in the while loop and assign it `1`.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
The developer wanted to stop the loop when `counter` is greater than `5`. 

1. Let's fix that by updating the condition to `counter <= 5`.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Be careful in using comparison operators. Use `<=`.

executableContent.instructions:
The developer has to join the strings, but he is using `-=`.

1. Inside the while loop's code block, update the `-=` operator so that it adds the string to `line`.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Use `+=` to add the string to the line.

executableContent.instructions:
Before we continue, try running the code. You'll notice that the waves still don't display. 

Every time the loop runs, we have to display the line to show the waves.

1. Display the `line` variable each time the while loop runs its code block.

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Use `console.log()` to display anything in the console.

executableContent.instructions:
Awesome job fixing the program. It now displays an asterisk `*` and a bunch of tildes `~` to simulate a beach.

Before we go on to make the output even cooler, run your code to see the current status.
